Saturday Papers: pound leaps on plot to halt no-deal Brexit
Saturday Papers: pound leaps on plot to halt no-deal Brexit
Citywire
August 17, 2019 Saturday 6:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 385 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And Cathay Pacific replaces chief executive as China ups pressure over protests.
Body
Top stories
•
The Times: The pound had its strongest gain against the euro in almost five months yesterday as 
Conservative Remain MPs talked up plans to block a no-deal Brexit.
•
Financial Times: Cathay Pacific replaced its chief executive on Friday after China increased pressure on 
Hong Kong businesses over anti-government protests.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Muddy Waters has hired an agency staffed by ex-CIA spooks to probe into alleged 
“significant deception” by bosses at Burford Capital.
•
Financial Times: Alibaba is to acquire rival NetEase’s cross-border online shopping platform.
•
Financial Times: City law firms are embroiled in a divisive battle over pay after they sharply increased 
remuneration for junior lawyers.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Prudential’s £12 billion annuity sale to Rothesay Life has been blocked at the 11th 
hour by the High Court.
Business and economics
•
The Guardian: A software glitch struck the London Stock Exchange early on Friday that prevented trading 
in the shares of Britain’s biggest companies.
•
Daily Mail: PwC has clinched a £16.5 million contract to manage the Government’s remaining assets from 
Northern Rock.
•
The Times: British defence group Ultra Electronics has won a billion-dollar contract to supply the US navy 
with sonobuoys.
•
Daily Mail: Ted Baker has joined hands with Next in an effort to push its children’s clothing lines out to 
more customers.
•
The Times: SSP Group, which was formerly part of Compass Group, has backed its chairman after a 
shareholder rebellion this year.
Saturday Papers: pound leaps on plot to halt no-deal Brexit
•
Financial Times: National Grid’s preliminary investigation into the blackout last week has raised the 
possibility that it was due to failure at Hornsea wind farm.
•
The Guardian: Norway has suspended donations to the Brazilian government’s Amazon Fund after a surge 
in deforestation in the South American rainforest.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Ryanair is seeking an injunction to prevent a planned two-day strike next week by its 
pilots based in the country.
Share tips, comment and bids
•
The Daily Telegraph (Questor share tips): HOLD Renew.
•
The Daily Telegraph: The future of 4,500 British Steel workers looks secure with Turkish buyer Ataer 
Holdings revealing plans to boost output at the stricken business.
•
The Daily Telegraph: The Scottish government has launched a surprise takeover of Ferguson Marine.

READERS WRITE
READERS WRITE
Financial Times (London, England)
August 17, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: MONEY;NEWS; Pg. 4
Length: 504 words
Body
The Lifetime Isa: three ways to invest A properly diversified portfolio would mitigate the risks in an economic 
downturn (also remembering that the FTSE 100 increased 60 per cent during 2009) and would recover eventually 
during this time. Regular contributions to a diversified portfolio is key to success. - AJM, via www.FT.com Sterling 
takes a pounding If sterling effectively falls by one third from pre-referendum to post hard Brexit that will increase 
consumer costs by about 6 per cent with no commensurate increase in income. That will worsen as government 
income will be the next casualty, so it is easy to see a 10 per cent decline in living standards, of which perhaps 2 
per cent has been felt so far. - Never vote Conservative again, via            www.FT.com Why I'll pay extra for holiday 
travel perks Car hire companies' charges are criminal. All the government has to do it is insist rental companies 
charge actual costs for repairs rather than standard fees (on repairs they never carry out...) and the problem would 
go away. - Stuart mellor, via            www.FT.com Fluffing up a generally poor experience with unnecessary costs 
really doesn't make the core experience any better. It merely justifies your belief in the expense you're paying.
As a Platinum Amex holder I can say I'd rather be at home than in a complimentary lounge and as a BA/SAS flyer 
I'd rather enjoy the more expensive core experience than pay additional fees with Ryanair. - Schnippzle, via 
www.FT.com We were told on our most recent hire that we would be charged extra if we returned the car 30 
minutes early.
When asked why, they said - with a very straight face - because we lost money as we could have hired your car to 
someone else. - JAFA, via www.FT.com "Premium" queue jumping is stressful because half the plane will have 
made the same calculation as you. - Fabricew, via            www.FT.com Inheritance tax: what does the future hold? 
Testators should exercise considerable caution before appointing an accountantcy, lawyer, surveying firm or the 
like to be executors.
READERS WRITE
Executors cannot be removed following the death of the testator and some of these firms charge hundreds of 
pounds per hour, plus Vat.
Executors should take advice from these firms,as needed or required, for specific advice for an agreed fee. - DR 
Sedley, via email Broadband: what price a reliable connection? I suggest you switch mobile network to one that has 
4G coverage in your home. Ofcom has a good postcode checker tool. Get a Sim and pop it in your existing 
handset. - Neymar, via www.FT.com What bizarre paranoia: a compulsion to check one's bank account daily in 
case there is fraud is not normal. - CremeBrullle, via            www.FT.com Money rarely compensates for loss. We 
all want reliable high-speed internet connections, but that comes at a huge cost. The project needs funds and a 
national plan. We need a government prepared to reorder its priorities and put a vast amount of capital into the 
project. - Citymoose, via            www.FT.com

BROKER RATINGS SUMMARY: Morgan Stanley Raises Hiscox To 
Overweight
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 16, 2019 Friday 4:32 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 283 words
Body
 The following London-listed shares received analyst recommendations Friday morning and Thursday afternoon:----
------FTSE 100----------MORGAN STANLEY RAISES HISCOX TO 'OVERWEIGHT' ('EQUAL-WEIGHT') - Price 
Target 1,780 PENCE (1,698) ----------PANMURE RESUMES TUI WITH 'HOLD' - TARGET 852 PENCE----------
BARCLAYS RAISES ASTRAZENECA PRICE TARGET TO 7800 (7600) PENCE - 'OVERWEIGHT'----------CREDIT 
SUISSE CUTS GLENCORE PRICE TARGET TO 300 (390) PENCE - 'OUTPERFORM'----------JPMORGAN CUTS

European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 16, 2019 Friday 10:41 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 230 words
Body
 American Depositary Receipts of European stocks were trading 0.93% higher at 977.54 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biotech firm Genfit (GNFT), and internet browser company Opera 
(OPRA), which climbed 6.3% and 5.8% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company Cellectis 
(CLLS), and 3D printer company Materialise (MTLS), which rose 4.3% and 3.2%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and 3D 
printer company voxeljet (VJET), which fell 7.5% and 2.4%, respectively. They were followed by semiconductor 
company Sequans Communications (SQNS), and dating app operator Spark Networks (LOV), which dropped 2.3% 
and 1.9%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), and Lloyds Banking Group (LYG), 
which rose 2.4% each. They were followed by Barclays Bank (BCS), and biopharmaceutical firm Amarin (AMRN), 
which were up 1.7% and 1.3%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), and biopharmaceutical company 
Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which lost 3.4% and 1.5% respectively. They were followed by software firm Endava 
(DAVA), and tobacco and consumer goods company British American Tobacco (BTI), which dropped 1.2% and 
0.8%.
Price: 15.85, Change: +0.93, Percent Change: +6.23
Load-Date: August 17, 2019
European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
End of Document
Ryanair expects minimal disruption from planned strikes
Ryanair expects minimal disruption from planned strikes
Business World (Digest)
August 16, 2019 Friday
Copyright 2019 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 434 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair expects minimal cancellations with affected passengers flying out at different times if pilots in Britain 
and Ireland go ahead with a two-day strike next week, the airline's chief people officer said on Thursday.
Ryanair staff unions in Ireland, Britain, Spain and Portugal have announced plans to strike in the coming weeks, a 
year after an initial wave of strikes over pay and conditions forced it to cancel hundreds of flights and hit its profits.
Members of its British pilot union, which the airline said represents half of its pilots there, voted last week to stage a 
two-day strike from Aug. 22, when directly employed pilots in Ireland also plan a strike.
Unionized Irish pilots represent less than half of Ryanair's pilots in its home market.
"Our hope is that we're going to cover the majority of the operation both in the UK and Ireland, and unless you hear 
from us, your flight is going ahead as normal," Eddie Wilson told Reuters in a telephone interview, adding that 
planned action by Portuguese cabin crew next week would be minor.
"We'll be protecting as a priority the summer destinations and there may be some cancellations on multi-frequency 
routes between Ireland, the UK or on UK domestics where people can make free changes, etc. There will not be 
travel chaos."
 
"OFF THE WALL"
Ryanair expects minimal disruption from planned strikes
Responding to the British Airline Pilots Association's call on Thursday to meet for mediated talks to resolve the 
dispute on pay and benefits, Wilson said Ryanair was still waiting on the union to reply to a legal letter stating it had 
to re-engage directly first, as per a deal struck last year.
Mediated talks broke down on Wednesday in Ireland, where a series of one-day strikes last year were quelled when 
concerns on transfers and promotions when settled.
Wilson said on Thursday that subsequent union claims for increases in total earnings of between 57% and 101% for 
some pilots were "off the wall," particularly at a time when "the world is falling apart aviation-wise."
Asked if there had been any impact on bookings, Wilson said that while talk of strikes could worry some potential 
customers, the holiday season of August is the time of the year where the airline has its highest number of advance 
bookings.
He also confirmed reports from unions that Ryanair is likely to close its base in Faro and two in the Canary Islands 
as part of plans to cut is presence on the ground in airports due to delays in the delivery of the grounded Boeing 
737 MAX.
A final decision has yet to be made on how many bases, jobs and routes will be cut as a result, Wilson added. 
(Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: September 11, 2019
End of Document
Airline Staff Were 'Disinterested' As Drunk Passenger Grabbed Emergency Exit Door Mid-Air
Airline Staff Were 'Disinterested' As Drunk Passenger Grabbed Emergency 
Exit Door Mid-Air
International Business Times News
August 16, 2019 Friday 7:46 AM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 544 words
Body
Aug 16, 2019( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair 
passengers recently had a terrifying experience after a man grabbed the emergency exit door mid-air and vomited 
all over himself. The incident took place aboard a Ryanair flight from Manchester, England, to Tenerife, Spain, 
earlier this month.Speaking to Sun Online on Wednesday[1], 47-year-old Alan Wild said he was with his girlfriend 
and stepson when the drunk passenger boarded the flight."We could hear some commotion going on at the front 
door...basically this guy got on the plane and was hammered. He got to the door and he was swearing at the cabin 
crew at the top of his voice to the point where my 11-year-old stepson commented on how drunk he was. 
He was telling them to p--- off and was being abusive and loud. But they didn't stop him boarding the plane,' he 
said.Things got worse when the unidentified passenger carelessly started walking on the emergency exit 
aisle."Some other passengers called a steward and said he shouldn't be sat there...this guy couldn't even put his 
seat belt on. If you read the emergency exit conditions, a legal requirement, you've got to be mobile, not hammered 
and in full control. But the cabin crew weren't interested. They kept telling everyone 'if it escalates, we will deal with 
it'. So, we went along with that,' Wild said.A while later, the passenger vomited on himself."You can imagine the 
smell. I saw his bag open...he had consumed three quarters of a bottle of whisky. The cabin crew left him covered 
in vomit for about 20 minutes. He was unable to deal with it himself, his friend was trying to sort him out. He then 
sat there spitting on the floor and hanging off the emergency exit door. His arms were all over it. Everyone was sat 
there thinking 'what is going on here'? Everyone was very frightened. Everyone within a 10-seat radius was well 
aware of the situation. It was awful,' he added.Upon reaching Spain, the drunk passenger was helped off the flight 
while all the other passengers were asked to wait in a hot shuttle bus for over 20 minutes.In a statement to Sun 
Online, a customer service representative for the airline said, "For the safety and comfort of our customers and 
crew we adhere to strict guidelines in relation to customers who are disruptive or under the influence of alcohol. In 
most circumstances customers who create a disturbance at check-in or the boarding gate are not permitted to 
board the plane.'"If a customer appears to behave in an unacceptable manner during a flight the crew will inform the 
Captain. The Captain and crew will then decide how to deal with the offending customer. Any customer who acts in 
a disruptive manner during a flight will be cautioned by the crew or Captain. If they continue to cause a disturbance 
the police will be alerted and will meet the flight on landing. We sincerely regret the inconvenience caused to the 
other passengers on this flight,' the representative added. In this representational photo, a Ryanair Boeing 737-800 
aircraft lands at Barcelona's 'El Prat' airport, Sept. 28, 2018. Photo: Pau Barrena/AFP/Getty Images [ 1]: 
https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/9719165/ryanair-terror-drunk-passenger-grabs-emergency-door-flight-tenerife/ 
Airline Staff Were 'Disinterested' As Drunk Passenger Grabbed Emergency Exit Door Mid-Air

Trade union urges Ryanair to attend talks to prevent strikes
Trade union urges Ryanair to attend talks to prevent strikes
City A.M.
August 16, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; TEASERS; Pg. 6
Length: 104 words
Byline: ALEXANDRA ROGERS
Body
A TRADE union yesterday urged Ryanair to attend talks to resolve the current dispute with its pilots over pay and 
working conditions.
The British Airline Pilots Association (Balpa), which has more than 10,000 members, has called on the budget 
airline to attend talks with the Acas conciliation service after pilots voted for strike action for Thursday 22 August 
and Monday 2 September.
Balpa recently held an industrial ballot of UK-based Ryanair pilots in which 80 per cent voted in favour of industrial 
action on a turnout of 72 per cent. The dispute centres on issues such as pensions, maternity benefit, allowances 
and pay.
Graphic
 
The dispute centres on issues such as pension, maternity benefit and allowances
Load-Date: August 16, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair 's pilots in Ireland to proceed with strike after talks fail
Ryanair's pilots in Ireland to proceed with strike after talks fail
Business World (Digest)
August 15, 2019 Thursday
Copyright 2019 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 253 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair's directly employed pilots in Ireland will strike for 48 hours next week, the Irish pilots' union Forsa/IALPA 
said on Wednesday, after mediated talks failed to bring an agreement with the company over the union's pay 
proposals.
To prevent a strike on Aug. 22-23, Ryanair management had needed to make a counter-proposal by Aug. 14 that 
properly addressed all areas of the union's claim, Forsa/IALPA had demanded.
"No such counter-proposal was made at the mediation meeting today," Forsa/IALPA said in a statement.
Ryanair has called on its pilots and the union to return to the mediation with proposals that take falling airfares and 
company profits into consideration, the airline said in a separate statement.
"We have done everything in our power to avoid disruption to our flights and our customers' holidays. However, no 
company can concede to grossly unreasonable demands from its highest paid workers... at a time when the airline 
industry is in crisis," said Ryanair Chief People Officer Eddie Wilson.
Pilots in the Forsa/IALPA trade union voted overwhelmingly in favour of industrial action last week after accusing 
Ryanair of stalling on talks since pay demands were submitted in late March.
Europe's largest budget airline suffered a number of strikes a year ago after a rocky start to its move to recognise 
unions for the first time, and it is now also facing strike action from its cabin crew in Spain over the company's plans 
to close several bases in the country. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Ryanair 's pilots in Ireland to proceed with strike after talks fail

Strikes and grounded planes may bring Ryanair down to earth
Strikes and grounded planes may bring Ryanair down to earth
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
August 15, 2019 Thursday 3:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: CIVIL PROJECTS
Length: 395 words
Highlight: A series of internal and external challenges faced by Ryanair comes on top of the announcement of 
disappointing results.
Body
The low-cost carrierÂ recently reported quarterly profits of EUR243m ($272m) in Q1 FY2019, a 21% drop 
compared to the previous year. Fuel costs increases and a 6% fall in average fares may explain these 
unsatisfactory results. This might be theÂ beginning of some tough times for the Irish airline, which is already 
embroiled in the Boeing 737 Max crisis and tricky HR issues. 
The company must now take action to limit the damage. Effective negotiations with its personnel and smart 
handling of the 737 Max difficulties would be a good start.Â But Ryanair also has to work on its brand image if it is 
to prevent current issues from affecting the company's long-term profitability. Pilot strikes are another black mark on 
the reputation of the carrierDisagreements regarding pensions, insurance, benefits and the pay structure 
betweenÂ management and its British pilots recently led the latter to call for five days of action in August and 
September. Irish personnelÂ have also indicated their intention to go on strike, while Spanish and Portuguese 
crews are likely to follow in their footsteps after announcing potential disruptions. GivenÂ the carrier faces fierce 
competition in terms of fares and level of service, having disgruntled employees could damage its image further in 
the eyes of the public and potentially lead to a loss in market share. The grounding of Boeing 737 MaxÂ aircraft is 
yet another crisis to be managed for Ryanair. The airline's declining fortunes have occurred amidÂ a reduction in 
the number of operating bases alongside plans to cut 900 jobs by next winter. Much of this is due to the delayed 
delivery of 135 Boeing 737 Max aircraft. Indeed, this model experienced two crashes that resulted in its worldwide 
grounding. It is hard to blame Ryanair for building itsÂ fleet from a range of aircraft that made economic sense, 
allowing it to drastically reduce its training and maintenance expenses at the same time. However,Â the Ryanair 
should ensure its current problems are better managed than in 2017 when it saw thousands of flights cancelled due 
to poor HR planning. AlthoughÂ CEO Michael O'Leary will attempt to use the negative publicity to the advantage of 
the airline, the extent of competition and signs of disaffection from the public keep growing. It would be ill-advised 
for the carrier to take its leading position for granted.
Strikes and grounded planes may bring Ryanair down to earth
Load-Date: August 21, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair 's Irish pilots agree to talks as strike looms
Ryanair's Irish pilots agree to talks as strike looms
Business World (Digest)
August 14, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 294 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair's directly employed pilots in Ireland agreed to attend mediated talks starting on Wednesday to avert a strike 
their trade union said would go ahead next week if the airline does not properly address a pay claim.
Europe's largest budget airline suffered a number of strikes a year ago after a rocky start to its move to recognize 
unions for the first time, and is under pressure again with pilots in its home market threatening to join cabin crew in 
Portugal and pilots in Britain on the picket line this month.
Irish pilots who are members of the Forsa/IALPA trade union voted overwhelmingly in favor of industrial action on 
Friday after accusing Ryanair of stalling on talks since pay demands were submitted in late March.
About a quarter of Ryanair's 350 pilots in Ireland staged a series of one-day strikes this time last year before 
concerns on transfers and promotions were settled. The talks on Wednesday will be overseen by the same 
mediator who brokered that deal.
"A substantive and meaningful counter-proposal from Ryanair management, which properly addresses all areas of 
the union’s claim, would need to be tabled tomorrow to prevent strike action next week," Forsa/IALPA said in a 
statement on Tuesday.
Members of Ryanair's British pilots union will stage the first of two multi-day strikes on Aug. 22, a day after 
Portuguese cabin crew are due to begin five days of action. Pilots in Spain are also considering a walk out.
Ryanair managed to quell last year's disputes by reaching deals with many unions in Europe on pay and 
allowances, but it has yet to move beyond recognition agreements with others and further angered staff by 
informing them two weeks ago that it had 900 more pilots and crew than it needed. (Reuters)
Ryanair 's Irish pilots agree to talks as strike looms
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: September 9, 2019
End of Document

during the 2nd quarter, according to its most recent disclosure with the SEC. The fund owned 2,979,797 shares of

Henderson Group PLC owned about 1.27% of Ryanair worth $191,124,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.

quarter. Hosking Partners LLP now owns 307,089 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$23,013,000 after buying an additional 220,688 shares during the period. Hedge funds and other institutional 
investors own  41.58% of the company's stock.  
RYAAY has been the subject of several recent analyst reports. JPMorgan Chase & Co. lowered Ryanair from a 
"neutral" rating to an "underweight" rating in a research report on Monday, July 29th. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair 
from a "sell" rating to a "strong sell" rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 30th. Canaccord Genuity lowered 
Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Wednesday, June 5th. Credit Suisse Group 
lowered Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "underperform" rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 23rd. 
Finally, HSBC lowered Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "reduce" rating in a research report on Wednesday, May 
22nd. Seven equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have issued  a hold rating and 
six have assigned  a buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair  has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus 
target price of $75.33. 
NASDAQ RYAAY  traded down $1.34 during trading hours on Wednesday, reaching $58.17. The company's stock 
had a trading volume of 8,512 shares, compared to its average volume of 729,424. The business's 50-day moving 
Janus Henderson Group PLC Purchases 603,738 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
average is $63.63. The company has a quick ratio of 1.08, a current ratio of 1.08 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.79.

estimate of ($0.64) by ($0.10). The firm had revenue of $1.45 billion for the quarter. Ryanair had a return on equity 
of 18.39% and a net margin of 10.47%.  Sell-side analysts anticipate that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 4.07 EPS 
for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Norwegian transatlantic flights from Ireland axed Airlines
Norwegian transatlantic flights from Ireland axed; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
August 14, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 286 words
Byline: RICHARD MILNE ;JANINA CONBOYE
Body
Norwegian Air Shuttle is scaling back its transatlantic ambitions as the struggling low-cost airline ends its services 
between Ireland and the US.
Norwegian said yesterday that it would cease flying from Dublin, Cork and Shannon to the US and Canada from 
September 15.
It blamed the grounding of Boeing's 737 Max aircraft after two fatal crashes for making the routes "no longer 
commercially viable".
It marks the first big retreat from Norwegian's rapid and expensive push into long-haul. The airline had hoped to 
shake up the sector by using planes such as the 737 Max and Boeing's Dreamliner to fly to lesser-known US 
destinations from regional European airports.
Under pressure from investors worried that its expansion could bring collapse, Norwegian has reversed course in 
recent months, saying it will no longer prioritise growth but will aim for better profitability. It raised fresh capital and 
replaced its chief executive and chairman.
"We take a strict approach to route management and constantly evaluate route performance to ensure we meet 
customer demand," said Matthew Wood, senior vice-president for longhaul commercial.
Norwegian transatlantic flights from Ireland axed Airlines
"Compounded by the global grounding of the 737 Max and the continued uncertainty of its return to service, this has 
led us to make the difficult decision to discontinue all six routes from Dublin, Cork and Shannon to the US and 
Canada."
Norwegian said it was in negotiations with pilots and cabin crew in Dublin "to ensure that redundancies remain a 
last resort". It will continue to fly to Oslo, Stockholm and Copenhagen from the Irish capital.
The airline, Europe's third-largest low-cost airline behind Ryanair and EasyJet, has also suffered technical issues 
on its long-distance routes.
Load-Date: August 13, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Averts Strike as Irish Pilots Agree to Resume Wage Talks
Ryanair Averts Strike as Irish Pilots Agree to Resume Wage Talks
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 14, 2019 Wednesday 6:20 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 89 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) averted a looming strike after a group of its Irish pilots, under the trade union Irish 
Airline Pilots' Association or Ialpa, agreed to resume wage talks with the airline, according to news reports.
The pilots were set to join their British and Portuguese counterparts in staging strikes this month, claiming Ryanair 
stalled negotiations after the group submitted their pay demands in March. Talks were set to resume Wednesday 
under the supervision of a mediator.
Price: 60.02, Change: +0.02, Percent Change: +0.03
Load-Date: August 15, 2019
End of Document

quarter.
